subclassFeature.name: Divine Soul
entries: Sometimes the spark of magic that fuels a sorcerer comes from a divine source that glimmers within the soul. Having such a blessed soul is a sign that your innate magic might come from a distant but powerful familial connection to a divine being. Perhaps your ancestor was an angel, transformed into a mortal and sent to fight in a god's name.
Or your birth might align with an ancient prophecy, marking you as a servant of the gods or a chosen vessel of divine magic.

A Divine Soul, with a natural magnetism, is seen as a threat by some religious hierarchies. As an outsider who commands sacred power, a Divine Soul can undermine an existing order by claiming a direct tie to the divine.

In some cultures, only those who can claim the power of a Divine Soul may command religious power. In these lands, ecclesiastical positions are dominated by a few bloodlines and preserved over generations.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Divine Soul feature}
When you learn a Sorcerer spell, you can also choose from the {@filter Cleric spell list|spells|class=cleric}, and it becomes a sorcerer spell for you.
When you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one spell from this feature with another Cleric spell of your choice.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

entries.caption: Divine Spells
rows: {@spell detect evil and good}, {@spell guiding bolt}
{@spell dispel evil and good}, {@spell greater restoration}

subclassFeature.name: Favored by the Gods
entries: {@i 1st-level Divine Soul feature}

Starting at 1st level, divine power guards your destiny. If you fail a saving throw or miss with an attack roll, you can roll {@dice 2d4} and add it to the total, possibly changing the outcome. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Bloodline
entries: Your innate magic comes from draconic magic that was mingled with your blood or that of your ancestors. Most often, sorcerers with this origin trace their descent back to a mighty sorcerer of ancient times who made a bargain with a dragon or who might even have claimed a dragon parent. Some of these bloodlines are well established in the world, but most are obscure. Any given sorcerer could be the first of a new bloodline, as a result of a pact or some other exceptional circumstance.

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Ancestor
entries: {@i 1st-level Draconic Bloodine feature}
At 1st level, you choose one type of dragon as your ancestor. The damage type associated with each dragon is used by features you gain later.
You can speak, read, and write {@language Draconic}. Additionally, whenever you make a Charisma check when interacting with dragons, your proficiency bonus is doubled if it applies to the check.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Resilience
entries: {@i 1st-level Draconic Bloodine feature}

As magic flows through your body, it causes physical traits of your dragon ancestors to emerge. At 1st level, your hit point maximum increases by 1 and increases by 1 again whenever you gain a level in this class.
Additionally, parts of your skin are covered by a thin sheen of dragon-like scales. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Draconic Bloodine feature}
When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with another spell of the same level, that deals your Draconic Ancestry damage, from any spell list.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Affinity
entries: Starting at 6th level, your draconic magic has an affinity with one of the damage types associated with dragons.

You have Resistance to the damage type associated with your ancestral dragon, and when you cast a spell that deals damage of that type, you can add your Charisma modifier to one damage roll of that spell

subclassFeature.name: Dragon Wings
entries: At 14th level, your innate magic can now manifest as draconic wings on your back. As a Bonus Action, you sprout those wings, gaining a Fly Speed equal to your Speed. The wings last until you dismiss them as a Bonus Action or you have the Incapacitated condition.
When the wings manifest, you decide whether they’re spectral or physical. If physical, you mustn’t be wearing something that obstructs them.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Presence
entries: Beginning at 18th level, you can channel the dread presence of dragons. As a Bonus Action, you can spend 5 Sorcery Points to draw on this power and exude an aura of awe or fear (your choice) within 60 feet. For 1 minute or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated} condition, each creature of your choice that starts its turn in this aura must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or have the {@condition Charmed} (if you chose awe) or {@condition Frightened} (if you chose fear) condition until the creature is outside the aura.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Magic
entries: You are a creature of shadow, for your innate magic comes from the Shadowfell itself. You might trace your lineage to an entity from that place, or perhaps you were exposed to its fell energy and transformed by it.

The power of shadow magic casts a strange pall over your physical presence. The spark of life that sustains you is muffled, as if it struggles to remain viable against the dark energy that imbues your soul. At your option, you can pick from or roll on the Shadow Sorcerer Quirks table to create a quirk for your character.

entries.caption: Shadow Sorcerer Quirks
rows: You are always icy cold to the touch.
When you are asleep, you don't appear to breathe (though you must still breathe to survive).
You barely bleed, even when badly injured.
Your heart beats once per minute. This event sometimes surprises you.
You have trouble remembering that living creatures and corpses should be treated differently.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Shadow Magic feature}

When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with an {@filter illusion or necromancy spell from the Sorcerer, Warlock, or Wizard spell list of the same level|spells|class=sorcerer;warlock;wizard|school=I;N|level=1;2;3;4;5}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Hound of Ill Omen
entries: {@i 6th-level Shadow Magic feature}

At 6th level, you gain the ability to call forth a howling creature of darkness to harass your foes. As a bonus action on your turn, you can expend 3 Sorcery Points and summon a Hound of Ill Omen to target one creature you can see within 120 feet of you. The hound uses the {@creature dire wolf}'s statistics (see the Monster Manual or appendix C in the Player's Handbook), with the following changes:

items: The hound is size Medium, not Large, and it counts as a monstrosity, not a beast.
It appears with a number of temporary hit points equal to half your sorcerer level.
It can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. The hound takes 5 force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.
At the start of its turn, the hound automatically knows its target's location. If the target was hidden, it is no longer hidden from the hound.

entries: The hound appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of the target. Roll initiative for the hound. On its turn, it can move only toward its target by the most direct route, and it can use its action only to attack its target. The hound can make opportunity attacks, but only against its target. Additionally, while the hound is within 5 feet of the target, the target has disadvantage on saving throws against any spell you cast. The hound disappears if it is reduced to 0 hit points, if its target is reduced to 0 hit points, or after 5 minutes. If the target is reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to expend 1 sorcery point to have it target another creature within 120 feet that you can see.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Magic
entries: Your innate magic comes from the wild forces of chaos that underlie the order of creation. You might have endured exposure to some form of raw magic, perhaps through a planar portal leading to Limbo, the Elemental Planes, or the mysterious Far Realm. Perhaps you were blessed by a powerful fey creature or marked by a demon. Or your magic could be a fluke of your birth, with no apparent cause or reason. However it came to be, this chaotic magic churns within you, waiting for any outlet.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Magic Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Wild Magic feature}

When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with an {@filter evocation or transmutation spell from the Sorcerer or Wizard spell list of the same level|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;Sorcerer (llas)|school=v;t}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Tides of Chaos
entries: {@i 1st-level Wild Magic feature}
You can manipulate the forces of chance and chaos to gain Advantage on one {@dice d20} Test. Once you do so, you must finish a Long Rest before you can use this feature again.
Immediately after you cast a Sorcerer spell with a spell slot before you regain the use of this feature, you automatically roll on the Wild Magic Surge table and regain the use of this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Magic Surge
entries: {@i 1st-level Wild Magic feature}

Your spellcasting can unleash surges of untamed magic. No more than once per turn, you can roll a {@dice d20} immediately after you cast a Sorcerer spell with a spell slot. If you roll a 20, roll on the Wild Magic Surge table to create a magical effect.

If the magical effect is a spell, it is too wild to be affected by your Metamagic, and if it normally requires Concentration, it doesn’t require Concentration in this case; the spell lasts for its full duration.

entries.caption: Wild Magic Surge
rows: Roll on this table at the start of each of your turns for the next minute, ignoring this result on subsequent rolls.
For the next minute, you can see any {@condition invisible} creature if you have line of sight to it.
A {@filter modron|bestiary|source=mm|search=modron} chosen and controlled by the DM appears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you, then disappears 1 minute later.
You cast {@spell fireball} as a 3rd-level spell centered on yourself.
You cast {@spell magic missile} as a 5th-level spell.
Roll a {@dice d10}. Your height changes by a number of inches equal to the roll. If the roll is odd, you shrink. If the roll is even, you grow.
You cast {@spell confusion} centered on yourself.
For the next minute, you regain 5 hit points at the start of each of your turns.
You grow a long beard made of feathers that remains until you sneeze, at which point the feathers explode out from your face.
You cast {@spell grease} centered on yourself.
Creatures have disadvantage on saving throws against the next spell you cast in the next minute that involves a saving throw.
Your skin turns a vibrant shade of blue. A {@spell remove curse} spell can end this effect.
An eye appears on your forehead for the next minute. During that time, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.
For the next minute, all your spells with a casting time of 1 action have a casting time of 1 bonus action.
You teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see.
You are transported to the Astral Plane until the end of your next turn, after which time you return to the space you previously occupied or the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.
Maximize the damage of the next damaging spell you cast within the next minute.
Roll a {@dice d10}. Your age changes by a number of years equal to the roll. If the roll is odd, you get younger (minimum 1 year old). If the roll is even, you get older.
{@dice 1d6} {@creature flumph||flumphs} controlled by the DM appear in unoccupied spaces within 60 feet of you and are {@condition frightened} of you. They vanish after 1 minute.

You turn into a potted plant until the start of your next turn. While a plant, you are {@condition incapacitated} and have vulnerability to all damage. If you drop to 0 hit points, your pot breaks, and your form reverts.
For the next minute, you can teleport up to 20 feet as a bonus action on each of your turns.
A {@creature unicorn} controlled by the DM appears in a space within 5 feet of you, then disappears 1 minute later.
You can't speak for the next minute. Whenever you try, pink bubbles float out of your mouth.
A spectral shield hovers near you for the next minute, granting you a +2 bonus to AC and immunity to {@spell magic missile}.
You are immune to being intoxicated by alcohol for the next {@dice 5d6} days.
Your hair falls out but grows back within 24 hours.
For the next minute, any flammable object you touch that isn't being worn or carried by another creature bursts into flame.
You regain your lowest-level expended spell slot.
For the next minute, you must shout when you speak.
You cast {@spell fog cloud} centered on yourself.
Up to three creatures you choose within 30 feet of you take {@damage 4d10} lightning damage.
You are {@condition frightened} by the nearest creature until the end of your next turn.
Each creature within 30 feet of you becomes {@condition invisible} for the next minute. The invisibility ends on a creature when it attacks or casts a spell.
You gain resistance to all damage for the next minute.
A random creature within 60 feet of you becomes {@condition poisoned} for {@dice 1d4} hours.
You glow with bright light in a 30-foot radius for the next minute. Any creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of you is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.
You cast {@spell polymorph} on yourself. If you fail the saving throw, you turn into a sheep for the spell's duration.
Illusory butterflies and flower petals flutter in the air within 10 feet of you for the next minute.
You can take one additional action immediately.
Each creature within 30 feet of you takes {@damage 1d10} necrotic damage. You regain hit points equal to the sum of the necrotic damage dealt.
You cast {@spell fly} on a random creature within 60 feet of you.
You become {@condition invisible} for the next minute. During that time, other creatures can't hear you. The invisibility ends if you attack or cast a spell.
If you die within the next minute, you immediately come back to life as if by the {@spell reincarnate} spell.
Your size increases by one size category for the next minute.
You and all creatures within 30 feet of you gain vulnerability to piercing damage for the next minute.
You are surrounded by faint, ethereal music for the next minute.
You regain all expended sorcery points.

subclassFeature.name: Bend Luck
entries: {@i 6th-level Wild Magic feature}

You have the ability to twist fate using your wild magic. When another creature you can see makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, you can use your reaction and spend 2 sorcery points to roll {@dice 1d4} and apply the number rolled as a bonus or penalty (your choice) to the creature's roll. You can do so after the creature rolls but before any effects of the roll occur.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Sorcery
entries: {@i 6th-level Wild Magic feature}
You learn the {@optfeature Unstable Spell|LLSS} Metamagic, but it does not count against your total number of Metamagics Known. Moreover, for you, it only costs 1 Sorcery Point to use.

subclassFeature.name: Controlled Chaos
entries: {@i 14th-level Wild Magic feature}
You gain a modicum of control over the surges of your wild magic. Whenever you roll on the {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB} table, you can roll twice and use either number.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Bombardment
entries: {@i 18th-level Wild Magic feature}

The harmful energy of your spells intensifies. Immediately after you cast a Sorcerer spell with a spell slot, you can create an effect of your choice from the Wild Magic Surge table, provided the effect casts a spell or restores all your expended Sorcery Points.
Once you use this feature, you can’t do so again until you finish {@dice 1d4} Long Rests.

subclassFeature.name: Acheron Ancestry
entries: Your magic stems from the plane of Acheron, the Infernal Battlefield. Unending battles take place across the entire plane between huge armies, with no chance of victory or cease-fire. This magic allows you to declare dominion over your foes, using both blade and spell to tear apart the battlefield. No matter how you gained your magic, you can use it bolster your martial prowess.

You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Acheron Origin Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Battle Grit
entries: {@i 1st-level Acheron Ancestry feature}

You gain proficiency with light armour, medium armour, and martial weapons. Additionally, you can use your Strength modifier, rather than your Dexterity modifier, to determine your AC while wearing armour. Finally, you can use any martial weapon you're holding as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

subclassFeature.name: Strike of Retribution
entries: {@i 1st-level Acheron Ancestry feature}

You're able to strike out at those who would dare attack you. When a creature hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to move up to your speed directly towards that creature and make a single melee weapon attack against it. If the attack hits, you deal an additional {@dice 1d6} force damage to the creature.
Additionally, when you hit a creature with this attack, you can spend up to 3 sorcery points. For each sorcery point you spend, you can push the creature up to 10 feet directly away from you.

subclassFeature.name: Conquest and Dominion
entries: {@i 6th-level Acheron Ancestry feature}

You can declare dominion over your foes. As a bonus action on your turn, you can spend a spell slot to channel your battle magic, gaining temporary hit points equal to 5 times the expended spell slots level + your Charisma modifier, as well as the following benefits:

items: Your melee weapon attacks deal an extra {@dice 1d6}  force damage to any target they hit.
You have advantage on Strength checks.

entries: These benefits last for 10 minutes, until you lose these temporary hit points, or until you use this feature again.

You can use this feature once without expending a spell slot, as if you had expended a spell slot at the highest level you can cast, up to 3rd level. Once you use this feature this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Onslaught
entries: {@i 14th-level Acheron Ancestry feature}

Your sorcery fuels your ferocity in battle. When you spend sorcery points on a metamagic options or features gained through your Acheron Ancestry, you gain a number of onslaught dice equal to the number of sorcery points spent, each of which are {@dice d4}'s. An onslaught dice gained this way lasts for 1 hour.

When you hit a creature with a weapon attack on your turn, you can expend a number of onslaught dice up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1). You add the expended onslaught dice to the damage of the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of Battle
entries: {@i 18th-level Acheron Ancestry feature}

You're able to fully embrace your martial magic, and can become an unstoppable force on the battlefield. As an action on your turn, you can expend 6 sorcery points, becoming an avatar of battle for 1 minute. While in this form, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain a base AC of 20 (your Strength or Dexterity modifier doesn't affect this number).
You gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
Your onslaught dice become {@dice d6}'s.

subclassFeature.name: Arctic Ancestry
entries: Your magic is tied to a creature, being, or place that embodies the harsh and cold nature of ice. Perhaps you were abandoned in a blizzard as a child, or a frost giant, white dragon, or other creature with a strong tie to ice and snow raised you as one of their own.

With this magic, you can chill your foes with the coldest ice, allowing you to slow their advance and freeze them to their core. You can also empower your defences with ice, using your arctic magic to better resist frigid conditions and dangerous environments.
Regardless of how you got this magic, and what you choose to do with it, the very essence of ice is embedded within you, waiting for an outlet.

subclassFeature.name: Arctic Origin Spells
entries: As an Arctic Ancestry Sorcerer, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Arctic Origin Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: One with the Arctic
entries: {@i 1st-level Arctic Ancestry feature}
Your bond with ice allows you to resist arctic landscapes. You're naturally adapted to cold climates, as described in chapter 5 of the Dungeon Master's Guide.

subclassFeature.name: Permafrost
entries: {@i 1st-level Arctic Ancestry feature}
Your spells call forth the chilling nature of ice. You learn the {@spell frostbite|XGE} cantrip, which doesn't count against your number of sorcerer cantrips known.

When you deal cold damage to a creature on your turn, you can use your bonus action to cover it with a thin layer of magical ice. Until the end of that creatures next turn, it's movement speed is reduced by 10 feet, and it has disadvantage on opportunity attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Iceborn
entries: {@i 6th-level Arctic Ancestry feature}

Your affinity with ice empowers your defences. You gain resistance to cold damage. Additionally, when you finish a short or long rest, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Snap Freeze
entries: {@i 6th-level Arctic Ancestry feature}

The ice you create is harsh, and those who fall to your spells are infused with your cruel magic. When you reduce a creature that's small or larger to 0 hit points with a sorcerer spell that deals cold damage, you can have its dead body turn to an ice statue.

An ice statue is an object with an AC of 10 and a number of hit points equal to your sorcerer level. If its reduced to 0 hit points, it shatters harmlessly. It is frozen matching the position of the creature that died, and if any part of it is destroyed, the creature suffers from similar deformities if it is restored to life.

You can spend 1 sorcery point as a bonus action to shatter a statue as long you can see it and it is within 60 feet of you. When an ice statue is shattered this way, all creatures within 10 feet of it must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking cold damage equal to half your sorcerer level + your Charisma modifier on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. That statue is then destroyed.

subclassFeature.name: Arctic Stride
entries: {@i 14th-level Arctic Ancestry feature}
Your body has completely adapted to cold climates. Difficult terrain comprised of ice or snow costs you no additional movement.

Additionally, you can enter solid ice and move from inside it to any other solid ice within 120 feet. Both of the solid ice (be it terrain or an object) must be at least the same size as you, and you must use 5 feet of movement to enter the ice. You instantly know the location of all other ice within 120 feet and, as part of the move used to enter the ice, can either pass into other solid ice or step out of the ice you're in. You appear in a spot of your choice within 5 feet of the destination ice, using another 5 feet of movement. If you have no movement left, you appear within 5 feet of the solid ice you entered.
You can step inside solid ice this way a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1), and regain all uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ring of Frost
entries: {@i 14th-level Arctic Ancestry feature}

Whenever you use your Permafrost feature to cover a creature in frost, you can spend 2 sorcery points to empower the ice. When you do so, the creature's speed is instead reduced to 0, and it can't take reactions.

subclassFeature.name: Absolute Zero
entries: {@i 18th-level Arctic Ancestry feature}

You can release primal, frigid magic that freezes anything it touches. As an action on your turn, you can spend 5 sorcery points to release this burst of freezing elemental power in a 60-foot radius, centered on you. Creatures of your choice in the radius must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature turns to ice, becoming subjected to the {@condition petrified} condition. The icy form lasts for a minute or until the creature takes damage. The effect ends on affected targets if you use this feature again.
Additionally, any water or other harmless liquid in the radius is immediately frozen, and doesn't melt until it takes fire damage from a spell of 7th level or higher.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Chaos
entries: Often confused for their brethren who use wild magic, sorcerers endowed with power from the primordial chaos use the merging elemental energy of the inner planes to cast spells seemingly at random. They are often thought of as madmen by wizards and other haughty spellcasters. They also share a kinship with elemental humanoids like the genasi.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Origin
entries: {@i 1st-level Primordial Chaos feature}

Your kinship with the primal elements awakens. You learn the {@spell control flames|xge}, {@spell mold earth|xge} and {@spell shape water|xge} cantrips. In addition you also learn to speak, read and write primordial.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Primordial Chaos feature}

You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Primordial Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with an {@filter evocation or transmutation spell from the Sorcerer or Wizard spell list of the same level|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;Sorcerer (llas)|school=v;t}.

subclassFeature.name: Reckless Casting
entries: {@i 1st-level Primordial Chaos feature}
You can attempt to cast a spell you haven't learned by using the chaotic energy of the inner planes. When you use this ability, you use your action and choose one of the following options:
Roll on the Reckless Casting table for cantrips and cast the resulting spell as part of this action.

Expend a spell slot and roll twice on the Reckless Casting table for its level, or the 5th-level table if the slot is 6th level or higher. Pick which of the two results you want to use and cast the resulting spell as part of this action.
If the spell you cast isn't a sorcerer spell, it is nonetheless a sorcerer spell for you when you cast it with this feature.

entries.name: Reckless Casting Tables; Cantrip
entries.caption: Cantrip
rows: Roll twice and cast each cantrip, but if you roll another 10 on either die, you cast nothing, wasting your action.

entries.name: Reckless Casting Tables; 1st-Level
entries.caption: 1st-Level Spells
rows: Roll twice and cast each spell, but if you roll another 10 on either die, you cast nothing, wasting your action but not the spell slot.

entries.name: Reckless Casting Tables; 2nd-Level
entries.caption: 2nd-Level Spells
rows: Roll twice and cast each spell, but if you roll another 10 on either die, you cast nothing, wasting your action but not the spell slot.

entries.name: Reckless Casting Tables; 3rd-Level
entries.caption: 3rd-Level Spells
rows: Roll twice and cast each spell, but if you roll another 10 on either die, you cast nothing, wasting your action but not the spell slot.

entries.name: Reckless Casting Tables; 4th-Level
entries.caption: 4th-Level Spells
rows: Roll twice and cast each spell, but if you roll another 10 on either die, you cast nothing, wasting your action but not the spell slot.

entries.name: Reckless Casting Tables; 5th-Level
entries.caption: 5th-Level Spells
rows: Roll twice and cast each spell, but if you roll another 10 on either die, you cast nothing, wasting your action but not the spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Sequestration
entries: {@i 6th-level Primordial Chaos feature}

Whenever a creature within 30 feet of you takes acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage you can use your reaction to give that creature resistance to the triggering damage type until the start of your next turn.

Also, you capture some of the incoming energy, storing it for your next melee or spell attack. The first time you hit with a melee attack or deal damage with a spell attack on your next turn, the target takes an extra {@dice 1d8} damage of the triggering type.
You can use this feature three times, and you regain any expended uses when you finish a short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Alteration
entries: {@i 14th-level Primordial Chaos feature}

When you cast a spell with a spell slot and the spell deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage, you can spend 1 sorcery point to substitute that damage type with one other type from that list (you can change only one damage type per casting of a spell). You replace one energy type for another by channeling elemental energy from the inner planes as you cast it.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Recklessness
entries: {@i 18th-level Primordial Chaos feature}

Whenever you use your Reckless Casting ability to cast a spell and you roll the same number on both dice, you can cast the resulting spell one spell slot level higher, if applicable. If you are rolling for two spells and and you roll the same number on both dice, only one of the spells is cast one spell slot level higher.

subclassFeature.name: Magnetism
entries: Most sorcerers born with powers over magnetism are born during great cosmic alignments, or in gravitational anomalies, and have a great affinity for metals and ores. Able to use their powers to influence and bend such metals as well as the forces of magnetism to their whims.

You could be a sorcerer born with an innate ferrokinetic sorcery that grants you mastery over the raw energies and materials of the universe by generating and controlling magnetic fields. Perhaps your powers manifested after the stars aligned in an ancient formation over your birthplace. Maybe they were granted to you by a mysterious patron or by a set of experiments that may have gone wrong. Whatever the case, it is undeniable that your control and mastery over metals is undeniable.

However your sorcery came to be, all magnetism sorcerers share one trait. This being that their eyes chrome over when they use their magic. You may roll or choose from the following table to determine what metal this is, or you may perhaps choose your own type of metal. The choice is yours.

subclassFeature.name: Alloy Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Magnetism feature}

As a Magnetism Sorcerer, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Alloy Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know. These are not the only magnetism spells that can be learned by you, but these are the ones that are innately known by you as you gain more experience.

subclassFeature.name: Iron Soul
entries: {@i 1st-level Magnetism feature}

You've begun to manifest the ability to shape metal to your will, with conjuring metal becoming second nature to you. You learn the {@spell shape metal|WMPS} cantrip, or another cantrip of your choice off the sorcerer spell list if you already know it.

Additionally, whenever you use your action to cast a Magnetism spell of 1st level or higher, you can use your bonus action to coat your skin in a shell of iron, encasing your body until the end of your next turn. This shell grants you an armor class equal to 10 + your Charisma modifier + the spell's level (up to a maximum of 5), but it reduces your movement speed by 10 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Metal Magus
entries: {@i 1st-level Magnetism feature}
You can alter mundane metals to a phenomenal degree. As an action, you can touch a metal object and apply one of the following effects:

items: You can increase the armor class of armor or a shield by 1.
You can increase one damage die on a weapon by one size, up to a maximum of a d12.
You can grant a weapon the reach property.
You can apply any effect of the {@spell shape metal|WMPS} spell.

entries: You may only have one of each of these effects manifested at a time, save for the last effect. You may have a number of items indefinitely altered by {@spell shape metal|WMPS} equal to your proficiency bonus.

If you use an effect a second time, or attempt to have more objects altered by {@spell shape metal|WMPS} that would exceed your proficiency bonus, the oldest instance of that effect immediately becomes undone.
You may dismiss any of these effects as a bonus action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Magnetic Propulsion
entries: {@i 6th-level Magnetism feature}
You’ve learned to use the magnetic objects around you to your fullest advantage. Propelling them with such force that they can completely, and utterly decimate your foes.

You may target an object you can see within 60 feet of you as an action, spend sorcery points depending on the object or creature’s size indicated by the list below to throw them violently at an object or creature within 60 feet of you.

Make a ranged spell attack roll against the object or creature you are targeting. On a successful hit, the target takes an amount of damage depending on the size of the object or creature thrown. All damage will be bludgeoning, slashing, or piercing damage depending on the improvised weapon used. If an object is thrown, both the object and the target take the damage. The object being thrown takes the damage rolled, even if the attack misses.

items: {@b Tiny/Small.} {@dice 2d6} plus spellcasting modifier.
{@b Medium.} {@dice 4d6} plus spellcasting modifier.
{@b Large.} {@dice 6d6} plus spellcasting modifier.
{@b Huge.} {@dice 7d6} plus spellcasting modifier.
{@b Gargantuan.} {@dice 8d6} plus spellcasting modifier.

entries: Lastly, your {@spell shape metal|WMPS} spell can now affect Medium objects.

subclassFeature.name: Electromagnetic Field
entries: {@i 6th-level Magnetism feature}

You’ve started to realize the true potentials of the power of magnetism, able to summon electromagnetic force fields to protect you from harm. As a reaction to taking damage, you can spend two sorcery points to negate the damage entirely. In addition, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) as the force field faintly lingers.

subclassFeature.name: Magnetic Manipulator
entries: {@i 14th-level Magnetism feature}
Your control over the magnetic properties in your body and other metallic objects increases, granting you a hover speed equal to your movement speed.

Also, as an action, on your turn you can target a single metal object or metal creature within 120 feet of you that weighs up to a number of pounds equal to your Sorcerer level x 100 and move them up to 30 feet in any direction. If you target an unwilling creature, that creature must succeed a Strength saving throw to be unaffected. If you are targeting an object that is being worn or carried the creature can make a Strength saving throw to not have the object move, this can be failed voluntarily.
In addition, your Magnetic Propulsion feature can now target creatures made of metal or wearing metal armor. An unwilling creature may make a Strength saving throw to be unaffected.

Lastly, your {@spell shape metal|WMPS} spell can now affect Large objects, and you can use it to manipulate complex objects (such as opening a lock or repairing a machine). If the object has an associated DC (for example, picking a lock), you make a spell attack roll against the DC.

subclassFeature.name: Magnetic Prison
entries: {@i 18th-level Magnetism feature}

You’ve truly mastered your powers of magnetism. As an action, by expending five sorcery points, you can call upon whatever metal surrounds you, even if that metal is but mere minerals beneath the earth. Any creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} within their metal binds for 1 minute, and take {@damage 3d10} magical bludgeoning damage as they’re crushed, half damage on a successful save. A creature may repeat the save at the end of their turns, ending the effect on a successful save.
Creatures who fail the saving throw at the end of their turns after being restrained take an additional {@damage 3d10} magical bludgeoning damage as they continue to be crushed.

In addition, when you levitate an object with your Magnetic Manipulator feature, you may expend sorcery points to increase the amount of weight you can lift. For every sorcery point you expend, you can lift an additional five hundred pounds.

subclassFeature.name: Emberheart
entries: Whether you stole your power from a noble Efreeti lord, were gifted it by an ancient fire drake, or were born near a gate to the Elemental Plane of Fire, you now carry within your soul an ember of pure elemental flame. This ember of arcane fire fuels your burning soul, inflames your passions, and allows you to perform wondrous and terrible feats of fire magic.

subclassFeature.name: Emberheart Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Emberheart feature}

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with another spell of your choice of the same level, {@filter that deals only fire damage, from any spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|damage type=!acid;!bludgeoning;!cold;fire;!force;!lightning;!necrotic;!piercing;!poison;!psychic;!radiant;!slashing;!thunder}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

entries.caption: Emberheart Spells
rows: {@spell summon elemental|tce|summon elemental (fire)}, {@spell wall of fire}

subclassFeature.name: Heart of Flame
entries: {@i 1st-level Emberheart feature}
Primordial flame empowers your spirit. You gain resistance to fire damage and you have advantage on saving throws to resist the {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions.
You also learn to speak, read, and write {@language Primordial||Ignan}, a dialect of {@language Primordial}, and the language of the Elemental Plane of Fire.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Fire
entries: {@i 6th-level Emberheart feature}

You can cause fire to erupt from the ruin of your foes. When you reduce a Small or larger creature to 0 hit points with a spell that deals fire damage, you can use your reaction to force creatures within 10 feet of it to make Dexterity saving throw. They take fire damage based on the size of the creature, as shown in the table below, on a failed save, and half as much on a success.
You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of this reaction when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Kindle the Flame
entries: {@i 14th-level Emberheart feature}

Your body is restored when you draw on the elemental flame. Whenever you cast a fire spell of 1st-level or higher, you can grant yourself temporary hit points equal to the level the fire spell was cast at + your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Inferno
entries: {@i 18th-level Emberheart feature}
Your flaming soul has become an inferno, making you more elemental than mortal. You no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you gain immunity to fire damage.
Also, when you take damage from a creature within 60 feet, you can force it to make a Dexterity saving throw as a reaction. On a failure, it takes fire damage equal to your level.

subclassFeature.name: Phoenix Soul
entries: Your power draws from the immortal flames of the legendary phoenix and the celestial radiance of the firebird. That power is a mixed blessing. Like the mythical creatures, you can invoke fiery energy and holy radiance, gaining the ability to cheat death itself. This power comes at a cost, as conflict is present within the very soul. The fire within you seethes, demanding to be unleashed while the celestial might of the firebird desperately tries to keep it in check, advocating redemption and forgiveness. Fire is a dangerous force, and phoenix sorcerers have a mixed reputation (deserved or not) that ranges from being reckless, confident that the essence of the phoenix can save them. Others strive to embrace the firebird's guidance, having the reputation of being proud, yet kind, seeking to guide and redeem those have lost their way. A rare few try and seek a balance between the destructive urges of the phoenix and the redeeming mercy of the firebird, though a successful attempt at this has never been officially documented.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Phoenix Soul feature}
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

entries.caption: Soul Spells
rows: {@spell aura of purity}, {@spell wall of fire}

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Soul
entries: {@i 1st-level Phoenix Soul feature}
As a bonus action, you can magically wreathe yourself in swirling fire or blinding radiance. For 1 minute, you gain the following benefits depending on which form you choose.
If you choose to call upon the destructive power of the phoenix, you gain the following benefits:

items: You shed bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.
Any creature takes fire damage equal to your Charisma modifier if it hits you with a melee attack from within 5 feet of you or if it touches you. You may only deal this damage once per turn.
Whenever you roll fire damage on your turn, the roll gains a bonus to equal to your Charisma modifier.

entries: If you choose to channel the celestial power of the firebird, you gain the following benefits:

items: You shed bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.
Whenever you would do damage with a spell that does fire damage, you may cause that damage to become radiant instead.

Once per turn, when you damage a creature with a spell that does radiant damage, you may force them to make a Constitution saving throw equal to your spell save DC or be blinded until the end of your next turn. If it is a spell that affects multiple creatures, only one creature of your choice must make the save.

entries: You can end this form early as a bonus action.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses on a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Duality of Flame
entries: {@i 1st-level Phoenix Soul feature}
As an action, you can magically ignite a flammable object you touch with your hand that isn't being worn or carried.

subclassFeature.name: Spark of Life
entries: {@i 6th-level Phoenix Soul feature}

If you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to instead be reduced to 1 hit point, and each creature of your choice within 10 feet of you takes fire or radiant damage of your choice equal to half your sorcerer level + your Charisma modifier.

If you use this feature while under the effects of your Mantle of Soul, this feature instead deals fire or radiant damage of your choice equal to your sorcerer level + twice your Charisma modifier, and your Mantle of Soul immediately ends.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest or you expend three sorcery points to channel this ability again.

In addition, when you use your Mantle of Soul feature, you now gain resistance to fire damage when you are using your phoenix form, and radiant damage when you are using your firebird form until the form ends.

subclassFeature.name: Duality of Flame Improvement
entries: {@i 6th-level Phoenix Soul feature}

The warmth and love of the firebird can radiate out from you if you so choose. As an action, you channel the warming presence of the firebird, making you and any creatures within a 5-foot radius of you immune to the effects of natural, environmental cold. If you are invited into a home or building, you can expand this warming presence to its inhabitants no matter how close they are to you.

subclassFeature.name: Nourishing Fire
entries: {@i 14th-level Phoenix Soul feature}
When you expend a spell slot to cast a spell that includes a fire or radiant damage roll, you regain hit points equal to the slot's level + your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Duality of Flame Improvement
entries: {@i 14th-level Phoenix Soul feature}

The wrath of the phoenix can be doled out on those who oppose you. You can ignite creatures using Duality of Flame. Any hostile creature that grapples you or otherwise comes into direct contact with your skin must succeed on Dexterity saving throw equal to your spell save DC or become alight with flames. At the start of each of its turns for 1 minute, or until the effect ends, the ignited creature takes {@dice 1d6} fire damage. If the target or a creature within 5 feet of it uses an action to put out the flames, or if some other effect douses the flames (such as the target being submerged in water), the effect ends. You may also suppress this effect at will.

subclassFeature.name: Soul's Embrace
entries: {@i 18th-level Phoenix Soul feature}

While under the effect of your Mantle of Soul feature, you can spend 5 Sorcery points and use your reaction to transform into a phoenix or firebird, gaining additional benefits based on the form you choose until the effect of Mantle of Soul ends.
While transformed into a phoenix, you gain the following benefits:

items: You have a flying speed of 60 feet and can hover.
You have immunity to fire damage. In addition, any spell or effect you create ignores resistance to fire damage and treats immunity to fire damage as resistance to fire damage.

As an action while transformed, you can call upon the destructive power of the phoenix and launch yourself through your foes. You can move up to your movement speed in any way you wish. Whenever you collide with a creature, that creature must make a Dexterity saving throw equal to your spell save DC or take {@dice 4d6} fire damage, taking half damage on a successful save. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks.

entries: While transformed into a firebird, you gain the following benefits:

items: You have a flying speed of 50 feet and can hover.
You have immunity to radiant damage. In addition, any spell or effect you create ignores resistance to radiant damage and treats immunity to radiant damage as resistance to radiant damage.

You call upon the healing radiance of the firebird, allowing you to now regain 10 hit points at the start of your turn up to half your maximum HP and as long as you have at least 1 hitpoint remaining. In addition, if you touch a willing creature, you can impart this blessing upon them rather than yourself. The blessing cannot be transferred back once you do so.

subclassFeature.name: Stormsoul
entries: Within you dwells a mote of pure elemental air, which grants you innate power over both breeze and storm. Whatever the origin of your power, your inner primal storm can drive you from whimsical and calm, to violence with little warning. Do you embrace the winds or do you seek to control the storm?

subclassFeature.name: Heart of Winds
entries: {@i 1st-level Stormsoul feature}

Drawing upon the tempestuous magic within you allows you to take flight. Beginning at 1st level, when you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher, you gain a temporary flying speed equal to your remaining movement speed, which lasts until the end of your current turn. This tempestuous flight does not provoke opportunity attacks, but If you end your movement while you are midair you fall to the ground at the end of your turn.

You also learn to speak, read, and write {@language Primordial||Auran}, a dialect of {@language Primordial}, and the language of the Elemental Plane of Air. By understanding Auran you can communicate with any creature that speaks Primordial, or one of its four dialects; Aquan, Auran, Ignan, and Terran.

subclassFeature.name: Stormsoul Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Stormsoul feature}

When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with another spell of the same level, {@filter that deals only lightning or thunder damage, from any spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|damage type=!acid;!bludgeoning;!cold;!fire;!force;lightning;!necrotic;!piercing;!poison;!psychic;!radiant;!slashing;thunder}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Stormborn
entries: {@i 6th-level Stormsoul feature}
The power of your inner storm has grown. At 6th level, you gain resistance to both lightning and thunder damage.

Also, whenever you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals lightning or thunder damage, you can force creatures of your choice within 15 feet to make a Dexterity Saving throw. Creatures take {@damage 2d6} lighting or thunder damage (your choice) on a failed save, and half as much on a successful save.
When you use this feature, you can expend additional Sorcery Points to increase the damage dealt by {@damage 1d6} for each additional Sorcery Point, up to a maximum of {@damage 6d6} damage.

Finally, you can use a bonus action on your turn to control the weather in minor ways within a 100-foot radius of you until the end of your next turn. For example, you could stop the rain, cause it to rain, change the current direction of the wind, or stop the wind completely.

subclassFeature.name: Windcaller
entries: {@i 14th-level Stormsoul feature}
You bend the wind itself to your call. At 14th level, you gain a flying speed of 60 feet, and while flying in this way your lower half becomes a tempestuous gale of swirling winds.

You also learn the {@spell wind walk} spell. It counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but doesn't count against your total number of Spells Known. As an action, you can cast wind walk without expending a spell slot. Once you do so, you must complete {@dice 1d6} long rests before you can cast it at no cost again.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Storm
entries: {@i 18th-level Stormsoul feature}
Your stormy soul has made you more elemental then mortal. Starting at 18th level, you no longer need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to lightning and thunder damage

In addition, when you take damage from a creature within 60 feet that you can see, you can use your reaction to rebuke them with elemental air. The attacker must make a Strength saving throw, and on a failed save, it takes thunder damage equal to your sorcerer level and is knocked back 20 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Waveborn
entries: Within you dwells a drop of pure elemental water, connecting you to the waters of the deepest oceans, babbling brooks, and frozen lakes. The gentle lapping of waves, the spray of the sea foam on the wind, the crushing darkness of the ocean depths; all these call you. Your watery magic can be as refreshing as the rains, or as destructive as great waves and flood waters.

subclassFeature.name: Heart of Water
entries: {@i 1st-level Waveborn feature}
The droplet of elemental water within your soul has altered your physical form. You gain the features detailed below:

items: You are resistant to cold damage.
You gain darkvision out to radius of 60-feet.
You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed, and you can breathe both air and water.

entries: You also learn to speak, read, and write {@language Primordial||Aquan}, a dialect of {@language Primordial}, and a language of the Elemental Plane of Water.

subclassFeature.name: Waveborn Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Waveborn feature}

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with another spell of your choice of the same level, {@filter that deals only cold damage, from any spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|damage type=!acid;!bludgeoning;cold;!fire;!force;!lightning;!necrotic;!piercing;!poison;!psychic;!radiant;!slashing;!thunder}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Curse of the Depths
entries: {@i 1st-level Waveborn feature}

Your magic carries a frozen curse. Starting at 1st level, when you deal cold damage to a creature with a spell, you can use your bonus action to cover a single target of that spell in frost, reducing its speed by a number of feet equal to five times your Charisma modifier (minimum of 5 feet).
This reduction lasts until the start of your next turn, unless a creature uses an action to scrape the frost off the target.

subclassFeature.name: Oceanic Resilience
entries: {@i 6th-level Waveborn feature}

Beginning at 6th level, you can temporarily take on a watery form to avoid harm. As a reaction when you are hit by an attack, you can grant yourself resistance to any bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage from the attack and move up to your full speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all uses when you finish a long rest. If you have no uses left, you can spend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Watery Form
entries: {@i 14th-level Waveborn feature}
The elemental water within your soul allows you to move as a flowing liquid. At 14th level, you gain the following benefits:

items: You are resistant to damage from opportunity attacks.
You can move through the space of an enemy creature but you cannot willingly end your movement there.
You can squeeze through gaps as narrow as 1 inch.
When you are underwater or using your swimming speed, you can take the {@action Dash} action as a bonus action.

As a bonus action, your body can extrude (or retract) a thin watery tentacle up to 10 feet long. You can use it to perform simple tasks, but it cannot attack, activate items, manipulate complex tools, or carry more than 10 pounds.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Deluge
entries: {@i 18th-level Waveborn feature}
Your watery soul has become a great sea, making you more elemental then mortal. Starting at 18th level, you don't need to eat, drink, or sleep, and you are immune to cold damage.
Also, as long as you are not incapacitated, when you are hit by an attack that is a critical hit, you can absorb the blow like flowing water, turning a critical hit into a normal hit.

subclassFeature.name: The Chained
entries: Once you were an unknowable, all powerful, and far reaching otherworldly entity, but now... now you are but shade of your former self, bound in mortal flesh. The eldritch essence from which you draw your magic is all that remains of your ancient terrible power. Maybe one day you will be able to regain your true power and punish those who did this to you...

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level The Chained feature}

The fragment of your former power grants you dark magic. When you learn a Sorcerer spell, you can choose from the {@filter Warlock spell list|spells|class=warlock}, and it becomes a Sorcerer spell for you.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.
When you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one spell from this feature with another Warlock spell of your choice.

entries.caption: Spells
rows: {@spell arms of hadar}, {@spell tasha's hideous laughter||hideous laughter}
{@spell arcane eye}, {@spell evard's black tentacles||black tentacles}

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Knowledge
entries: {@i 1st-level The Chained feature}

You have access to lost knowledge from eons long dead. You gain proficiency in {@skill History}, and you learn to speak, read, and write, {@filter two exotic languages|languages|type=exotic} of your choice.

Also, while you sleep during a long rest, you can commune with the ancient knowledge you once had, focusing your mind on one person, place, or object you interacted with in the past 24 hours. Make a Charisma ({@skill History}) check to learn one fact about the subject, often one forgotten to modern scholars.

subclassFeature.name: Unknowable Mind
entries: {@i 6th-level The Chained feature}
Your elder mind grants you advantage on saving throws to resist being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, or have your thoughts read.

Additionally, when you are forced to make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw to resist the effects of a spell, you can use your reaction to force a creature within 30 feet to become the target of the spell instead of you.
Once you use this reaction you must complete a long rest before you can use it again. If you have no uses left, you can spend a spell slot of 3rd-level or higher to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Otherworldly Step
entries: {@i 14th-level The Chained feature}

Beginning at 14th level, using your eldritch power allows you to move through cracks in reality itself. Whenever you expend a spell slot, you can instantly teleport a number of feet equal to 5 times the level of the spell slot you spent, appearing in an unoccupied space of your choice within range.

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Revelation
entries: {@i 18th-level The Chained feature}
Upon reaching 18th level, you can use your action to briefly assume a form that resembles your terrible former power. For the next minute, you gain the following benefits:

items: You can cast {@spell tasha's hideous laughter||hideous laughter} at 1st-level spell as a bonus action on each turn, without expending a spell slot.
You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed.

You can move through other creatures and objects. If you end your movement inside an object or creature, you are shunted to the nearest unoccupied space, and take {@damage 1d10} force damage for every 5 feet you were forced to travel.

entries: Once you use this feature to transform, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest, unless you spend 7 Sorcery Points to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Right
entries: Once in a generation, a divinely chosen ruler is born amongst the people. Some cults and countries seek out these blessed rulers, trusting the gods to select their leader. However, the existence of these chosen Sorcerers can pose a significant threat to those currently in power. While some will willingly step aside to let the will of the gods rule, other less honorable leaders will hunt down these challengers to their power.
As a Divine Right Sorcerer, you are granted great power, but with that power also comes responsibility. Will you lead the your people to destruction or into a new golden age?

subclassFeature.name: Divine Mark
entries: {@i 1st-level Divine Right feature}

A Divine Mark has manifested somewhere on your body signifying the type of ruler you are to become. Select one of the Divine Marks below. Once chosen, your Mark can't be changed short of the {@spell wish} spell or divine intervention.

entries.name: Mark of Elegance
entries: You will be known for diplomacy. You gain proficiency in {@skill Persuasion}, and you add double your proficiency bonus to Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks.

entries.name: Mark of Guile
entries: You will be known for your cunning. You gain proficiency in {@skill Deception}, and you can add double your proficiency bonus to all Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks.

entries.name: Mark of Might
entries: You will be known for your strength. You gain proficiency in {@skill Intimidation}, and you add double your proficiency bonus to all Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks.

subclassFeature.name: Royal Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Divine Right feature}

When you gain a level in this class, you can replace one spell from this feature with a {@filter conjuration or enchantment spell of the same level from the Cleric, Sorcerer, or Wizard spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;cleric;Sorcerer (llas)|school=c;e}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Words of Authority
entries: {@i 1st-level Divine Right feature}

Your voice has been imbued with divine authority, and it is difficult for the weak willed to resist your commands. Also beginning at 1st level, when you target a creature within 5 feet that can hear you with an enchantment spell, you can impose disadvantage on the creature's saving throw.

Once you use this feature to impose disadvantage, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Upon reaching 2nd level, if you have no uses of this feature remaining, you can expend 2 Sorcery Points to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Words of Vigor
entries: {@i 6th-level Divine Right feature}

The power of your voice uplifts those that choose to follow you. As a bonus action, you can spend a number of Sorcery Points, up to your Charisma modifier and grant one creature that can hear you within 30 feet {@dice 1d8} temporary hit points per Sorcery Point expended.
The temporary hit points from this ability only last until the end of the creature's next short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Regal Presence
entries: {@i 14th-level Divine Right feature}

Upon reaching 14th level, your presence inspires confidence in all who follow you. When a friendly creature within 60 feet that can see or hear you, is forced to make a saving throw, you can grant them advantage on their roll as a reaction.
Additionally, your presence cows those who stand before you. The range of your Words of Authority becomes 15 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Command
entries: {@i 18th-level Divine Right feature}

Upon reaching 18th level, you become a legendary figure of authority for your people, and your voice is blessed with increased divine power. You learn the {@spell divine word} spell. It becomes a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against your total number of Spells Known. As an action, you can cast {@spell divine word} without expending a spell slot. Once you do so, you must finish a long rest before you can cast divine word at no cost again.

subclassFeature.name: Faeblood
entries: Every so often, a mortal catches the attention of a lord or lady of the Fey. Often, the object of affection or offspring of this relationship is gifted wondrous arcane ability beyond that of other mortals. However, these mortal infatuations are usually brief, and the mortals are left to learn to use their power with little supervision or instruction. Weather you were chosen by a powerful Fey, or were the child of such a relationship or you have been blessed with the whimsical power of the Feywild.

subclassFeature.name: Fey Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Faeblood feature}
When you learn a Sorcerer spell, you can also choose from the {@filter Bard spell list|spells|class=bard}, and it becomes a Sorcerer spell for you.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.
When you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one spell from this feature with another Bard spell of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Heartsight
entries: {@i 1st-level Faeblood feature}
Your affinity with Fey magic grants you heightened empathic abilities. You gain proficiency in {@skill Insight}, and you add double your proficiency bonus to your Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks.

In addition, you can use an action to touch a creature and attempt to read its current emotional state. Make a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, contested by its Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check. On a success, you learn the target's alignment and its surface level emotions. Celestials, fiends, and undead automatically fail. Creatures are unaware you attempted to read their heart.

subclassFeature.name: Seasonal Attunement
entries: {@i 6th-level Faeblood feature}

Beginning at 6th level, you can align yourself with one of the seasons like a true Fey. At the end of each long rest, choose a season and gain the benefits listed below. Each season grants you a resistance and advantage on certain rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Gateway Magic
entries: {@i 14th-level Faeblood feature}

Your magic allows you to slip between the Feywild and the material plane. Starting at 14th level, after you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher, can choose to teleport to an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet that you can see.
When you use this feature, you can spend Sorcery Points to increase its range by 10 feet for each Sorcery Point.

subclassFeature.name: Intoxicating Presence
entries: {@i 18th-level Faeblood feature}
You exude the intoxicating presence of an Archfey. Starting at 18th level, creatures of your choice within 15 feet of you have disadvantage on saving throws to resist enchantment spells.

subclassFeature.name: Greensinger
entries: There are many reclusive sages who learn to wield the magic of nature, but a rare few are born with an innate connection to that magic. Known as Greensingers, these wild sorcerers are able to magically manipulate plants, and can even sprout vines from their flesh in order to move about the world. How did you come to bear this primal power? Were you chosen by an ancient forest to serve as its guardian, or are you the child of an ancient prophecy, raised from birth by a Druidic Circle?

subclassFeature.name: Verdant Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Greensinger feature}
When you learn a Sorcerer spell, you can also choose from the {@filter Druid spell list|spells|class=druid}, and it becomes a Sorcerer spell for you.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.
When you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one spell from this feature with another Druid spell of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Vigorous Vines
entries: {@i 1st-level Greensinger feature}

Beginning at 1st level, you can use a bonus action to extrude (or retract) a thin, yet vigorous, vine from your body up to 10 feet in length. You can use this vine to perform simple tasks, but it can't be used to attack, manipulate tools, or activate items, and it cannot carry more than 10 pounds.
You can extrude a total number of vines at one time equal to your proficiency bonus. The vines share your Armor Class and they each have hit points equal to your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Grasping Growth
entries: {@i 6th-level Greensinger feature}

Your Vigorous Vines can grow up to 15 feet in length. While your vines are extruded, you can use a bonus action to attempt to {@action grapple} a creature within 5 feet of a Vine, making a Charisma ({@skill Athletics}) check.

Also, while you have at least two vines extruded, you gain a climbing speed equal to your movement speed, and you can climb on difficult surfaces including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check. Your vines must be able to reach the surface you wish to climb.

entries.name: Grappling from a Distance
entries: Remember, a creature {@condition grappled} by you, no matter how far from your body, is able to attack whatever limb, or Vigorous Vine, you are using to grapple it.

subclassFeature.name: Creeping Defense
entries: {@i 14th-level Greensinger feature}

Upon reaching 14th level, your vines can grow up to 20 feet in length. Also, when you are hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to block the incoming blow with one of your vines. If the incoming damage destroys your vine, you take any additional damage that exceeds your vine's hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Sapping Grip
entries: {@i 14th-level Greensinger feature}

At 14th level, your vines are able to drain the vitality of your foes. At the start of your turn, each creature grappled by your vines takes necrotic damage equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1), and you gain temporary hit points equal to the total necrotic damage dealt to all grappled creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Greensong
entries: {@i 18th-level Greensinger feature}

You and the natural world have become one. Starting at 18th level, you can use an action to enter the Greensong, a state of pure harmony with nature. For the next minute, or until you are incapacitated, you gain the benefits listed below:

items: You immediately extrude the maximum number of Vines.
The reach of your Vines temporarily becomes 30 feet.

When you take the {@action Attack} action, you can make an attack, or attempt a {@action grapple} with each Vine. You use Charisma for the attack rolls, and they deal magical bludgeoning damage equal to {@damage 1d8} + your Charisma modifier on hit.

subclassFeature.name: Hellspawn
entries: Most mortals who wield the fiendish power of the hells do so through strict contracts with devils and Archdevils. However, some cultists and other mortals connect with more chaotic demonic powers and become Hellspawn. Though not always evil, Hellspawn are fueled by the chaotic magic of the Abyss.

subclassFeature.name: Abyssal Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Hellspawn feature}

Whenever you gain a Sorcerer level, you can replace one spell from this feature with another {@filter conjuration or evocation spell of the same level from either the Sorcerer, Warlock, or Wizard spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;warlock;Sorcerer (llas)|school=c;v}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Demonic Form
entries: {@i 1st-level Hellspawn feature}

At 1st level, you gain the ability to undergo a wild abyssal transformation, unleashing the demonic power bound within your soul. As a bonus action, you can take on your Demonic Form. While transformed, you retain your game statistics, your body becomes demonic in appearance, and you gain the following benefits for one minute:

items: Your hands become wicked natural weapons that deal {@damage 1d8} slashing damage on hit, and you can use your Charisma, in place of Strength, for their attack and damage rolls.
When not wearing armor, you gain a bonus to your Armor Class equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1).
As a bonus action, you can grant yourself temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

entries: Your transformation ends early if you are {@condition incapacitated}, or you end it as a bonus action. You can transform a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
Additionally, you learn to speak, read, and write {@language Abyssal}, the language of demons and all creatures of the Abyss.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 6th-level Hellspawn feature}
You can attack twice, instead of once, when you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of those attacks.
Finally, while you are in your Demonic Form, your natural weapon attacks count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Fiendish Resistance
entries: {@i 14th-level Hellspawn feature}

Beginning at 14th level, your hellish power can shield you from harm. As a reaction, when you take damage while in your demonic form, you can expend a spell slot to reduce the incoming damage by an amount equal to five times the level of the spell slot you expend.

subclassFeature.name: Archdemonic Form
entries: {@i 18th-level Hellspawn feature}

You have mastered the fiendish power that dwells within you. Beginning at 18th level, your Demonic Form lasts until you choose to end it. Also, while you are in your Demonic Form, you gain the following additional benefits:

items: You can take the {@action Dash} action as a bonus action.
You are immune to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks.
When you hit a creature with a natural weapon attack it takes an additional {@damage 1d8} magical slashing damage.

subclassFeature.name: Ironmonger
entries: Often born during times of great war and strife, Ironmonger Sorcerers have an affinity for all things forged for use in war. They thrive in the midst of battle, wielding potent war magic on the front lines. Ironmongers are formidable foes, and are sought after by captains and conquerers for their ability to turn the tide of any battle, no matter how hopeless.

subclassFeature.name: Iron Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Ironmonger feature}

Whenever you gain a level, you can replace one spell from this feature with another {@filter abjuration or conjuration spell of the same level from the Sorcerer or Wizard spell list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;Sorcerer (llas)|school=a;c}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Armaments of War
entries: {@i 1st-level Ironmonger feature}

The arcane power within your soul grants you an affinity with the armaments of war. You gain proficiency with all light and medium armor, shields, and all {@filter simple and martial weapons that lack the heavy or two-handed properties|items|source==b0~b0|type=!futuristic;martial weapon;!modern;!renaissance;simple weapon;!treasure|rarity=none|property=!heavy;!two-handed}.

subclassFeature.name: Blade of Strife
entries: {@i 1st-level Ironmonger feature}

You can conjure up the signature weapon of an Ironmonger Sorcerer, the Blade of Strife. As a bonus action, you conjure this mystical Blade at a point you can see within 60 feet. It lasts for 1 minute or until you use this feature again.

When you conjure the Blade, you can make a melee spell attack against one creature within 10 feet of it. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d8} magical slashing damage. As a bonus action, you can move the Blade up to 30 feet and repeat the attack.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all of your expended uses when you finish a long rest, unless you expend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher to summon it again.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 6th-level Ironmonger feature}
You can attack twice, instead of once, when you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your Sorcerer cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Iron Smite
entries: {@i 6th-level Ironmonger feature}
Once per turn when you hit a Large or smaller creature with a melee weapon or Blade of Strife attack you can force it to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save it falls {@condition prone}.

subclassFeature.name: Dancing Blade
entries: {@i 14th-level Ironmonger feature}

At 14th level, you gain increased mastery with your Blade of Strife. As a reaction, when a creature within 10 feet of your Blade is hit by an attack, you can attempt to deflect the blow with your Blade, and grant the creature a bonus to its Armor Class equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of +1).
Also, your Blade of Strife now deals {@damage 2d8} damage on hit.

subclassFeature.name: Storm of Blades
entries: {@i 18th-level Ironmonger feature}

You have become a god of warfare and lay waste to your foes. Starting at 18th level, you can use your action to destroy your Blade of Strife in a storm of arcane iron shards and force two creatures of your choice within 30 feet of your Blade to make a Dexterity saving throw. Targets take {@damage 6d8} magical slashing damage on a failure, and half as much on a success.

When you use this action, you can spend a spell slot to target additional creatures with of your choice within 30 feet of your Storm of Blades. You can target a single additional creature for a 1st-level spell slot, plus one additional creature for each level of spell slot above 1st.

subclassFeature.name: Vampiric Soul
entries: The dark magic of undeath is a path to great power for those who are willing to pay the price. Many of the most powerful undead creatures will grant their followers a portion of their dark sorcery in return for their service. Evil vampires, long dead mummy lords, and sinister liches have all been known to curse their most loyal followers with sorcerous abilities.
What have you sacrificed to gain this sinister sorcery? Are you sworn in service to a dark lord or a creature of undeath?

subclassFeature.name: Blood Magic
entries: {@i 1st-level Vampiric Soul feature}

You have been gifted an affinity for sorcerous blood magic. You can expend your hit points in place of spell slots by spending four hit points for each level of the spell slot you would have spent. Both your current hit points and maximum hit points are reduced by the number of hit points you spend. This hit point reduction cannot be lessened in any way, and the reduction to your hit point maximum lasts until the end of your next long rest.

Moreover, when you slay a creature with a sorcerer spell of 1st-level or higher, you gain temporary hit points equal to twice the level of the spell slot you expended to cast the spell. Temporary hit points you gain from this feature can be used in place of your hit points for your Blood Magic spellcasting.

subclassFeature.name: Vampiric Spells
entries: {@i 1st-level Vampiric Soul feature}

When you gain a level in this class, you can replace a spell from this feature with a {@filter necromancy or enchantment spell, of the same level from the Sorcerer, Warlock, or Wizard list|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=wizard;warlock;Sorcerer (llas)|school=e;n}.
You learn certain spells at the sorcerer levels noted in the table below. They count as sorcerer spells for you, but they don't count against your number of Spells Known.

subclassFeature.name: Undead Resilience
entries: {@i 6th-level Vampiric Soul feature}
